items.content:
Tule.slo:

Kerndoel 54 Kunstzinnige oriëntatie

De leerlingen leren beelden, muziek, taal, spel en beweging te gebruiken, om er gevoelens en ervaringen mee uit te drukken en om er mee te communiceren.

Kerndoel 55 Kunstzinnige oriëntatie

De leerlingen leren op eigen werk en dat van anderen te reflecteren.

IPC:

MP1 thema: Tijd-detectives - Speuren in het verleden

Kunst 1.2

De leerlingen zijn in staat om verschillende materialen en technieken te gebruiken.

Kunst 1.3

De leerlingen zijn in staat om voorstellen te doen om hun eigen werk te verbeteren.

Kunst 1.4

De leerlingen zijn in staat om hun mening te geven over kunstwerken.

Activiteit 1 = de leerlingen leren een fossiel na te maken.

Activiteit 2 = de leerlingen leren om een foto van een schilderij na te maken.

Activiteit 3 = de leerlingen leren om een 'schilderij-foto' maken en om deze na te tekenen.

Activiteit 4 = de leerlingen leren een foto te maken en deze voor de helft verder te tekenen.

Time needed: 60 mins

Kerndoel: 54 IPC: 1.2

Description:

Open the Prowise lesson 'fossils' (1) Talk to the students about fossils and how to make a fossil. Click on the picture of a fossil of a leaf you will then go to the page in Prowise 'How to make a fossil'. When you click on the blue arrow you will go back to the main page of the Prowise lesson Fossils. When you click on the picture with the shells (2) you will see the recipe how to make fossils using plaster of paris.

Functional language:

I'm going to make a fossil from paper. I'm going to make a fossil from plaster of paris. I'm going to make a fossil of a fish. I'm going to make a fossil of a shell. I'm going to make a fossil of a ........

Vocabulary:

fossil, paper, plaster of paris, fish, shell.

Resources:

1 2

Time needed: 30 mins

Kerndoel: 54, 55 IPC: 1.2, 1.3, 1.4

Description:

Open the Prowise lesson 'from painting to photo'. (1) Talk with the students about the subject that in earlier years there were no cameras and when people wanted to have a photo that they had to make a painting about the subject.
Click on number 3. You go to the page with pictures from paintings. The children are going to make their own photo in groups. The photo has to look like one of the paintings in the prowise presentation. When all the children have taken their photo discuss with the childeren which photo is which painting. Ask the childeren to say what is good about the photo and what they could do better next time when they take a picture.
Click on the blue arrow and you go back to the main page 'from painting to photo'.

Functional language:

I'm going to take a picture. You have to stand here. You have to sit here. Are you ready? Next time.....

Vocabulary:

Photo, picture, camera, sit, stand, chair, table, left, right, ready.

Resources:

1

Time needed: 45 mins

Kerndoel: 54, 55 IPC: 1.2, 1.3, 1.4

Description:

Open the Prowise lesson 'from painting to photo'. (1) Talk with the students about the subject that in earlier years there were no cameras and when people wanted to have a picture that they had to make a painting about the subject.
Click on number 1. You will go to the page with pictures (half a picture and half a painting). The children are going to make a selfie and print the selfie. Cut the selfie in half. Now ask the childeren to complete the picture to draw the other half. When everybody has finished the picture they can show their own picture to the group. Choose three children to say something good about the picture and something that can be better next time.
Click on the blue arrow and you go back to the main page 'from painting to photo'.

Functional language:

I'm going to take a selfie. I will print the selfie. I will cut the selfie in half. I'm going to get the pencils. I am going to draw myself using the right colours.

Vocabulary:

Selfie, photo, camera, picture, print, cut, colour.

Resources:

1

Time needed: 45 mins

Kerndoel: 54, 55 IPC: 1.2, 1.3, 1.4

Description:

Open the Prowise lesson 'from painting to photo'. (1) Talk with the students about the subject that in earlier years there were no cameras and when people wanted to have a picture that they had to make a painting about the subject.
Click on number 4. You will go to the page with a picture from a picture frame. Print the picture frame twice. In one picture frame cut out the middle. The children need to take a photo of their 10 o'clock snack they have brought to school e.g. fruit/cookie/food.Then give the children the other picture frame and ask them to make a painting of the fruit/cookie/food.
When you click on the yellow arrow you can see some examples. When the children are ready you can show their photos and painting to the class. Ask the pupils to say what is good about them and what was difficult.
Click on the blue arrow and you will go back to the main page 'from painting to photo'.

Functional language:

I am taking a picture of my..... I am making a painting of my......

Vocabulary:

Picture, camera, painting, picture frame, paint.

Resources:

1

Tule.Slo:

Kerndoel 51, Oriëntatie op jezelf en op de wereld, tijd

De leerlingen leren gebruik te maken van eenvoudige historische bronnen en ze leren aanduidingen van tijd en tijdsindeling te hanteren.

Kerndoel 52, Oriëntatie op jezelf en op de wereld, tijd

De leerlingen leren over kenmerkende aspecten van de volgende tijdvakken: jagers en boeren; Grieken en Romeinen; monniken en ridders; steden en staten; ontdekkers en hervormers; regenten en vorsten; pruiken en revoluties; burgers en stoommachines; wereldoorlogen en holocaust; televisie en computer. De vensters van de canon van Nederland dienen als uitgangspunt ter illustratie van de tijdvakken.

Kerndoel 53, Oriëntatie op jezelf en op de wereld, tijd

De leerlingen leren over de belangrijke historische personen en gebeurtenissen uit de Nederlandse geschiedenis en kunnen die voorbeeldmatig verbinden met de wereldgeschiedenis.

IPC:

MP1 Thema: Tijd-detectives - Speuren in het verleden

Geschiedenis 1.3

De leerlingen zijn in staat om vragen over het verleden te stellen en te beantwoorden

Geschiedenis 1.4

De leerlingen zijn in staat om kernwoorden en uitdrukkingen te gebruiken met betrekking tot het verstrijken van de tijd.

Geschiedenis 1.5

De leerlingen zijn in staat om gebeurtenissen en objecten in volgorde te rangschikken

Geschiedenis 1.6

zijn in staat om verschillen te herkennen tussen hun eigen leven en dat van mensen die in het verleden hebben geleefd

Geschiedenis 1.7

De leerlingen zijn in staat om feiten uit het verleden te achterhalen uit verschillende informatiebronnen.

Geschiedenis 1.9

De leerlingen begrijpen dat gebeurtenissen en daden van mensen oorzaken en gevolgen hebben

Activiteit 1 = In deze activiteit gaan de leerlingen met elkaar in gesprek over waar materialen vandaan komen en hoe ze vroeger en nu gebruikt worden. De leerlingen krijgen een materiaal toegewezen waarvan ze het gebruik, vroeger en nu, dienen te tekenen.

Activiteit 2 = In deze activiteit bekijken de leerlingen filmpjes over stambomen, maken ze zelf een stamboom en presenteren ze deze vervolgens aan hun medeleerlingen.

Activiteit 3 = In deze 3 activiteiten leren de leerlingen hoe fossielen ontstaan door middel van liedjes, filmpjes en een spelletje.

Activiteit 4 = In deze activeit leren de kinderen dat vroeger schilderijen werden gemaakt om iets vast te leggen en dat er nu camera's worden gebruikt.

Time needed: 30 mins

Kerndoel: 51 IPC: 1.3, 1.5, 1.9

Description:

Bring some old objects into the classroom, for example some old stamps, toys or coins. You can also ask the children to bring something old from home to school. Discuss the use of the materials in the past and nowadays. How have the objects changed? Give the children a white piece of paper and fold it into two. Let them draw the object in the past on the left side, for example: an old iron. Ask them to draw on the right side what it looks like now, for example an electric iron . Let the children show their work to the class: 'This is a … '/ 'Is it in the past?' / 'Is it nowadays?' / 'Yes, it is' / 'No, it isn't'. For an extension you can see (1) a simple reading book about searching for treasure.

Functional language:

This is a … , Is it in the past?, Is it nowadays?, Yes, it is, No, it isn't

Vocabulary:

past, nowadays, coin, toy, stamp, etcetera

Resources:

1

Time needed: 10 mins for part 1 and 30 minutes for part 2

Kerndoel: 51 IPC: 1.5 (history)

Description:

Part 1:
Open the prowise lesson family tree.
In the middle of the page you will see four pictures. Behind every picture there is a little movie about a family tree. Here you can practise the words and sentences.
Talk to the children about their family members.

Part 2:
If you click in the bottom left hand corner and the bottom right hand corner there are examples to show you how to make a family tree. When you click on back you will go back to the main page from the family tree.
For the preparation of this lesson the children need to bring photos from their family. They will need to use their photos to make their own family tree. When their family tree is finished they can present it to the other children in the class or in little groups.

Functional language:

This is my family, He is my husband/son, She is my wife/sister, They are my grandparents/children, He has a brother, Who is he/she?

Vocabulary:

Family tree, family, mother, father, brother, sister, grandmother, grandfather, boy, girl, people, women, men, uncle, aunt, son, daughter, parents, grandparents, cousin, husband, wife, children, grandchildren, grandson, granddaughter, niece, mother, father, nephew, sister- in- law, brother-in-law, father-in-law, mother-in-law, daughter-in-law, son-in-law.

Resources:

1.

Time needed: 3x10 mins

Kerndoel: 51 IPC: 1.4 1.7

Description:

Open the Prowise lesson 'fossils' (1). When you click on the picture where they are digging a dinosaur, you will go to the page with two songs about fossils. Song A (2) and song B (3). When you click on the blue arrow you will go back to the main page fossils.

When you click on the picture where people are digging in the sand you will go to the page with a game and movies from the American museum of natural history. The game (4) and movies (5). When you click on the blue arrow you will go back to the main page fossils.

When you click on the shell you will go to the page with four movies where they explain how fossils arise (6, 7, 8). When you click on the blue arrow you will go back to the main page fossils.

Functional language:

I'm going to watch the movie.
Vocabulary:

Stone remains, skeleton, amber, mold, sediment, mold, earthquake, fossil, mud, paleontologist, layers, rock, extinct.

Resources:

1 2 3

4 5 6


7 8

Time needed: 10 mins

Kerndoel: 52, 53 IPC: 1.5, 1.6, 1.9

Description:

Open the Prowise lesson 'from painting to photo'. (1) Talk with the students about the subject that in earlier years there were no cameras and when people wanted to have a picture that they had to make a painting about the subject.
Click on number 2. You will go to the page with a picture from a painting and camera's. The children have to put the pictures in the right order from old to new.
Click on the blue arrow and you will go back to the main page 'from painting to photo'.

Functional language:

This painting/camera is really old. This camera is older. This camera is new. This camera is newer. This camera is the newest. This camera is the oldest.

Vocabulary:

Old, older, eldest new, newer, newest painting, camera.

Resources:

1

Tule.Slo:

Kerndoel 14 Engels
De leerlingen leren in het Engels informatie te vragen of geven over eenvoudige onderweren en zij ontwikkelen een attitude waarbij ze zich durven uit te drukken in die taal.

Kerndoel 44 Oriëntatie op jezelf en op de wereld, natuur en techniek

De leerlingen leren bij producten uit hun eigen omgeving relaties te leggen tussen de werking, de vorm en het materiaalgebruik.

IPC:

MP1: Tijd-detectives - Speuren in het verleden

Natuur 1.24

De leerlingen kennen de namen en sommige eigenschappen van hout, stof, steen, metaal, leer, aardewerk, papier en bot

Natuur 1.27

De leerlingen zijn in staat om overeenkomsten en verschillen tussen materialen te beschrijven.

Natuur 1.28
De leerlingen zijn in staat om materialen naar hun eigenschappen te rangschikken in groepen.

De leerlingen leren de namen en eigenschappen van materialen en leren ze te categoriseren.

Activiteit 1 = Een activiteit om overeenkomsten en verschillen tussen materialen te beschrijven.

Activiteit 2 =

Activiteit 3 = Een activiteit om materialen naar hun eigenschappen te rangschikken in groepen.

(This practising language activity links in with Activity 2)

Game: Quiz

Challenge:Match the picture to the word

Functional language:
This is... / this is a(n)...
Vocabulary:
Wood, metal, paper, cardboard, plastic, leather, bone, cloth, pottery, brick, rock, glass.

Instructions:
Open the Prowise Quiz Materials (1). You can play the quiz individually with pro connect with the children on a tablet or with the whole group on the digiboard.

Resources:

(1)

(This practising language activity links in with Activity 2)

Game: Quiz

Challenge:Match the picture to the word

Functional language:
This is...
Vocabulary:
Hard, soft, cold, warm, rough, smooth, shiny, dull.

Instructions:
Open the Prowise Quiz Materials 2 (1). You can play the quiz individually with pro connect with the children on a tablet or with the whole group on the digiboard.

Resources:

(1)

(This practising language activity links in with Activity 2)

Game: Quiz

Challenge:Match the picture to the word

Functional language:
This (is)...
Vocabulary:
See-through, not see-through, waterproof, not waterproof, floats, doesn't float, magnetic, not magnetic.

Instructions:
Open the Prowise Quiz Materials 3 (1). You can play the quiz individually with pro connect with the children on a tablet or with the whole group on the digiboard.

Resources:

(1)

Time needed: 90 mins

Kerndoel: 44,14 IPC: 1.24, 1.27, 1.28

Description:

Prior to carrying out this activity the children should have been introduced to the vocabulary for materials. They should be able to name the common materials e.g. metal, brick, wool, glass, plastic and paper.

To introduce the vocabulary for the properties of materials there is a song and interactive activity on prowise (1). Click on the arrow to move from one page to the other.

Also See 'Properties of materials' poster (3) and (4) from twinkl for classroom display or use in the classroom.

Research activity

Provide the children with hand magnifiers and a variety of objects (old and new) made from different materials: wood, metal, paper, cardboard, plastic, leather, bone, cloth, pottery, brick, rock and glass. Give each child an object and a magnifier. Tell the children to use all their senses (except taste) to explore these materials. Ask them to think of words to describe the object they've been given (e.g. hard, soft, shiny, rough, bumpy, bendy.)

Ask the pupils to look through the magnifier to find out what material the object is made from. You want them to identify and name the common materials and some of the properties associated with each.

Ask the class to sort the objects into groups of the same material. You could label one box 'wood', one box 'metal', etc and ask the children to sort the objects into the correct boxes. Children can then check the contents of the boxes to see if all the objects have been correctly placed.

Now ask them to look at the box containing wooden items and ask: How do you know these objects are made from wood? How can you tell? (They may say about the knots, the colour, the smell etc.) Next look at the other box containing metal items and ask: how do you know these objects are not wood? (They may say they are harder, colder to touch, shinier etc.) You can record the vocabulary the children use to describe the properties and display these on the outside of the boxes of the different materials.

Functional language:

What is it?, Can you label?, Can you find? and Circle it.

Vocabulary:

Wood, metal, paper, cardboard, plastic, leather, bone, cloth, pottery, brick, rock, glass, hard, soft, cold, warm, rough, smooth, shiny, dull, see-through, not see-through, waterproof, not-waterproof, floats, doesn't float, magnetic, not magnetic.

Resources:

1 2 3

4

Time needed: 90 mins

Kerndoel: 44,14 IPC: 1.24, 1.27, 1.28

Description:

Prior to carrying out this activity the children should have been introduced to the vocabulary for materials. They should be able to name the common materials e.g. metal, brick, wool, glass, plastic and paper.

To introduce the vocabulary for the properties of materials there is a song and interactive activity on prowise (1). Click on the arrow to move from one page to the other.

Also See 'Properties of materials' poster (3) and (4) from twinkl for classroom display or use in the classroom.

Recording activity

Divide the class into groups. Ask the groups to sort a collection of objects in different ways, according to different properties. You can use the prowise activity(2) with the children first before they do it themselves in groups. Click on the arrow to move from one page to the next.

For example:

Hard or soft

Cold or warm

Rough or smooth

Shiny or dull

See-through or not see through

Waterproof or not waterproof

Floats or does not float

Magnetic or not magnetic

Functional language:

What is it?, Can you label?, Can you find? and Circle it.

Vocabulary:

Wood, metal, paper, cardboard, plastic, leather, bone, cloth, pottery, brick, rock, glass, hard, soft, cold, warm, rough, smooth, shiny, dull, see-through, not see-through, waterproof, not-waterproof, floats, doesn't float, magnetic, not magnetic.

Resources:

1 2 3

4

Time needed: 40 mins. 20 mins for the research, and 20 mins for the recording activity.

Kerndoel: 44 IPC: 1.2, 1.3, 1.4, 1.5

Description:

Science Activity: research of materials.

Research activity: Materials age in different ways. Give some examples: we know when people are old because their skin ages, or their hair gets grey. Can you think of another material that wrinkles as it ages/ gets old? For example: leather: Who's wearing leather shoes? How can we tell if they are new or old? The children should survey the materials used in the school environment (indoors and outdoors) and look for signs (or evidence) of how materials are ageing. Look for wood that is fading, splitting or rotting, metal that is rusting, paint peeling, algae or moss forming on brickwork. Different groups or pairs could look at different materials at different areas of the school.

Recording activity.

Encourage the children to make notes or sketches, or take photographs of what they find.They could complete charts to compile their class findings. Materials: paint, wood, metal, plastic, pottery: Is it (very) old or new?
Back in the classroom look at your collection of old objects- look for signs of ageing or decay. Sort the objects into old or new. Can the children explain the results? What are the similarities and differences?

Functional language:

Is it old or new? It is made of ....plastic, wood, metal. Is it waterproof?

Vocabulary:

Material, wood, iron, paint, metal, plastic, pottery, paper.
